channel.title: 2D tile map file format
channel.description:
File format for a 2D tile based region (think pokemon-esque)
First byte = region id 4 bits - number of different referenced tilesheets 1 byte for each difference referenced tilesheet id, first one would be relative tilesheet id 0, etc.
For each tile: 1 bit - blocked? (for those that don't know, means you can't walk through it) 3 bits - layer empty? (111 would mean all 3 layers have a tile id, 010 would mean only the middle layer has a tile id) 2 bytes for each tile layer: (if 3 active layers, would be 6 bytes for the tile, etc) AAAABBBB BBCCCCCC A = 4 bits, relative tilesheet ID B = 6 bits, tile X from tilesheet C = 6 bits, tile Y from tilesheet
[u][b]Example:[/b][/u]
[u]Header:[/u] 01001011 (Region 75) 0011 (3 different tilesheets referenced in this map) 00000011 [Tilesheet 3, relative ID 0] 00011001 [Tilesheet 25, relative ID 1] 00101000 [Tilesheet 40, relative ID 2]
[u]Actual map:[/u] [i]Tile 0, 0[/i] 0 (not blocked) 110 (2 active layers) 0001 (relative ID 1) 010111 010110 (23, 22) 0000 (relative ID 0) 000001 000000 (1, 0) [i]Tile 1, 0[/i] 1 (blocked) 100 (1 active layer) 0010 (relative ID 2) 010110 010110 (22, 22) etc
[u]Map file size assuming a 64x64 map with all 3 layers always used: (note this is a worst-case scenario, most of the time you wont be using all 3 layers)[/u] 26 kilobytes
Thoughts, comments, ideas on how I could make it smaller, what you think I should change, etc?

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Or, you can just be lazy and write a format that’s quick to parse but mostly unconscious to compression, then use some sort of RLE or dictionary-based compression algorithm that massively sizes it down. That’s mostly what I do these days, though it’s also really fun to develop your own lossy compression algorithm that stacks with a RLE or dictionary-based, meaning you can even size the data down significantly further, at the cost of minimal precision loss.

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:27, topic:520285”]Sorry if you’ve already accounted for it or someone has already suggested it but 2D maps generally have a lot of contiguous regions, so your map format should feature a method of referencing tiles which have been already been defined (if that makes any sense).

On a game I’m currently fiddling with, the map is stored using ASCII letters, and D-I are reserved for referencing nearby tiles so when parsing if the game sees a D, it means the current tile is the same as the one to left, E means the current tile is the same as the one above etc etc. RLE in then used so these regions are nicely compressed

Having said that, you’d probably get better compression using an algorithm which already exists.[/quote]There’s no need to compress them nowadays. There wasn’t in a lot of even Gameboy games, where your workable RAM was only 4KB and the ROM was 1MB max. The only data compressed in the Pokemon generation 1 games are the Pokemon. The Megaman Xtreme games don’t compress their maps. Neither do several other games.

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Sorry if you’ve already accounted for it or someone has already suggested it but 2D maps generally have a lot of contiguous regions, so your map format should feature a method of referencing tiles which have been already been defined (if that makes any sense).

On a game I’m currently fiddling with, the map is stored using ASCII letters, and D-I are reserved for referencing nearby tiles so when parsing if the game sees a D, it means the current tile is the same as the one to left, E means the current tile is the same as the one above etc etc. RLE in then used so these regions are nicely compressed

Having said that, you’d probably get better compression using an algorithm which already exists.

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Thanks for the info, Bowser jr. It is a bit weird how they layout their layers, but it makes a lot more sense now. I think all David can pull from that system is possibly a third layer for pseudo-weather, but I think an overlay or post-processing shader effects would be more convenient, depending on how he does it. So I still stand by the 2 layer + objects list style.

item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:24, topic:520285”]EDIT: I messed up a bit up here. Forgot that I fixed the bug by making the Region give back a dummy Tile when asking for number 30. I know this isn’t a nice solution, so I hope Taharok can help you.[/quote]Yea, that made it work perfectly for me as well. I’m just trying to figure out where my math/logic is wrong so that it’s giving me an index 30 in the first place (technically it doesn’t show index 30 even if you return a dummy tile, so I just want to know what’s making it return 30 in the first place. (It wont go below 0, but it will go above 29… meh)

EDIT - I fixed it:
Replaced

with

int tilesWide = (int)((getWidth() - offsetX)/tileSize); if((getWidth() - offsetX)%tileSize != 0) { tilesWide++; }And the same for tilesTall

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

That is all of the relevant code right there. All of the calculations are there, and xI and yI are arbitrary.

EDIT - Oh it should be noted that the class this is in is a Canvas, which is what getHeight() and getWidth() refer to.

The get size in pixels methods are just the width/height of the region multiplied by the tile width (32)

But here is some more I guess, if it is of any use (pls ignore stupid class name):

[code=java]package client.gui;

import java.awt.Canvas;
import java.awt.Color;
import java.awt.Graphics2D;
import java.awt.Toolkit;

import client.Constants;
import client.game.world.map.Region;
import client.game.world.map.Tile;

public class GameScreen extends Canvas {

private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
private final double UPDATE_TIME_STEP = 1/60.0;
private double updateCounter = 0;
private double oldTime = 0;

/*
 *Temp variables 
 *
 */
int counterX, counterY;
private Region myRegion;

public GameScreen(int width, int height) {
	myRegion = new Region(30, 30);
	setBounds(0, 0, width, height);
	setIgnoreRepaint(true);
	requestFocus();
	setFocusable(true);
}

public void gameUpdate() {
	counterX+=20;
}

public void render(Graphics2D g2D) {
	drawRegion(myRegion, g2D, 500, 200+counterX/20);
}

public void run() {
	double elapsed = getDeltaTime(getSystemTime());
	while (true) {
		elapsed = getDeltaTime(getSystemTime());
		if (elapsed > UPDATE_TIME_STEP)
			elapsed = UPDATE_TIME_STEP;
		updateCounter += elapsed;


		while (updateCounter >= UPDATE_TIME_STEP) {
			gameUpdate();
			Graphics2D g2D = (Graphics2D) getBufferStrategy().getDrawGraphics();
			render(g2D);
			g2D.dispose();
			getBufferStrategy().show();
			Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().sync();
			updateCounter -= UPDATE_TIME_STEP;
		}
		try {
			Thread.sleep(1);
		} catch (InterruptedException e) {
			System.out.println("GameScreen run() interrupted");
		}
	}
}

public double getSystemTime() {
	return System.nanoTime() / 1000000000.0;
}

public double getDeltaTime(double timer) {
	double elapsed = timer - oldTime;
	oldTime = timer;
	return elapsed;
}
public void drawRegion(Region r, Graphics2D g2, int xI, int yI) {
	int mapWidth = r.getWidthPixels();
	int mapHeight = r.getHeightPixels();
	int originX = xI - getWidth()/2;
	int originY = yI - getHeight()/2;
	if(originX < 0) {
		originX = 0;
	}
	if(originX + getWidth() > mapWidth) {
		originX = mapWidth - getWidth();
	}
	if(originY < 0) {
		originY = 0;
	}
	if(originY + getHeight() > mapHeight) {
		originY = mapHeight - getHeight();
	}
	int tileSize = Constants.TILE_SIZE;
	int offsetX = -(originX % tileSize);
	int offsetY = -(originY % tileSize);
	int xStart = originX/tileSize;
	int yStart = originY/tileSize;
	int tilesWide = (getWidth() - offsetX)/tileSize + 1;
	int tilesTall = (getHeight() - offsetY)/tileSize + 1;
	for (int y = 0; y < tilesTall; y++) {
		for (int x = 0; x < tilesWide; x++) {
			Tile t = r.getTile(x+xStart, y+yStart);
			t.getImage().draw(g2, offsetX + x * tileSize, offsetY + y * tileSize);
			g2.setColor(Color.WHITE);
			g2.drawString((x+xStart) + ":" + (y+yStart), offsetX + x * tileSize, offsetY + 32 + y * tileSize);
		}
	}
	g2.translate(-originX, -originY);
	g2.setColor(Color.RED);
	g2.fillRect(xI-10, yI-10, 20, 20);
}

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Interesting, Bowser.

Well I need some help, I’m brainfarting while drawing the code to center the map around the player.

public void drawRegion(Region r, Graphics2D g2, int xI, int yI) { int mapWidth = r.getWidthPixels(); int mapHeight = r.getHeightPixels(); int originX = xI - getWidth()/2; int originY = yI - getHeight()/2; if(originX < 0) { originX = 0; } if(originX + getWidth() > mapWidth) { originX = mapWidth - getWidth(); } if(originY < 0) { originY = 0; } if(originY + getHeight() > mapHeight) { originY = mapHeight - getHeight(); } int tileSize = Constants.TILE_SIZE; int offsetX = -(originX % tileSize); int offsetY = -(originY % tileSize); int xStart = originX/tileSize; int yStart = originY/tileSize; int tilesWide = (getWidth() - offsetX)/tileSize + 1; int tilesTall = (getHeight() - offsetY)/tileSize + 1; System.out.println(tilesTall); for (int y = 0; y < tilesTall; y++) { for (int x = 0; x < tilesWide; x++) { Tile t = r.getTile(x+xStart, y+yStart); g2.setColor(t.getColor()); g2.fillRect(offsetX + x * tileSize, offsetY + y * tileSize, tileSize, tileSize); g2.setColor(Color.WHITE); g2.drawString((x+xStart) + ":" + (y+yStart), offsetX + x * tileSize, offsetY + 32 + y * tileSize); } } g2.translate(-originX, -originY); g2.setColor(Color.RED); g2.fillRect(xI-10, yI-10, 20, 20); //my cute little square player :3
xI yI are just temporary variables I’m using for debugging at the moment, those would normally be the coordinates of the center of the player. And obviously Tile wont have a color variable, that’s also for debugging until I make some maps.

Anyways, I have the update loop changing xI and yI around so I can watch the map move, and it’s working great if the origin is moving up and left (ie, the index => 0), but if the index => r.getWidth() [the number of tiles wide the region is], I will get an out of bounds exception right at the end. In other words, it’s trying to draw the x or y index being 30 when it can only go 0-29.

Picture reference. In this case, the map was scrolling down until it hit 29, but it would then try to render [X, 30] and give me a NPE.

I have a feeling one of my calculation logics is just a tiny bit off, and I could use a fresh pair of eyes.

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:19, topic:520285”]Layer 1: Non solid parts of house, trees…

What does that mean?[/quote]
You don’t colide with them, but they are drawn over you.

A little mistake in my layer list.
Solid parts of roofs/treetops are in both layer 1 and 2. (Don’t ask me why)

EDIT: Pokemon emerald’s layers make no sense at all. But shows some pattern.
Layer 0 is text boxes and interface. Layer 1 is nearly the same as in Zelda, but some include some solid parts of the roof and chimney(?). Layer 2 makes is terrain(ish). Layer 3 contain textures to be drawn under elements like dirt paths so such elements can be used on many different terrains.

EDIT 2:
If I were to make the layers myself it would be.
0: Non solid items that would be drawn over you.
NPC/Monster/player layer.
1: Elements on the map like rocks, houses… with transparent background.
2: Basic terrain. (Grass, dirt…)
3: Lighting/weather effects. In Zelda it isn’t mapped 1:1 to the rest of the map, so it is more dynamic than baking it into the rest of the layers.
X: You also need the collision map as described by you earlier, but this should be handled by the map elements and not in the file.
Taharok might not like it, but it makes map making quite dynamic. And before Taharok kills me, you would combine 1 and 2 on runtime, so you draw them quicker.

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Taharok: You wanted to know what the different layers in a GBA game does, so I tested with Zelda: lttp.
Layer 0: Infomation about items, life… (GUI)
Layer 1: Non solid parts of house, trees…
Layer 2: Everything else.
Layer 3: Light and weather.
Layer 4: You and other NPCs and map (Map as map of your enviroment, not the game area) elements. (Not really a layer of the map)

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:15, topic:520285”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=638783.msg4306100#msg4306100 date=1369846742]
Just a bit of feedback on the per-tile information, I very rarely see games need 3 layers. They may provide the illusion of having three layers, since there are tiles you can walk on (layer below), tiles you cannot walk on (same layer), and tiles that are above you when you walk on them (layer above). Nevertheless, even for tiles that are semi-transparent being drawn on a background tile, that’s still only 2 visual layers. I pretty much never see transparent tiles on transparent tiles on an opaque tile (3 layers). Reconsider just implementing 2 layers and implementing some nice editor tricks for making it seem like 3. Unless, of course, I’m misunderstanding your intended goals.[/quote]GBA game use 4 layers. I’m sure the DS does the same or something similar.[/quote]

Interesting. What are the four layers used for? Do you have any screenshots to show a situation where anything more than 2 layers is actually necessary? I can see situations where 4 layers would be very nice, but typically it’s overkill. This is true even for terrain blending in modern 3D engines, as well. A lot of modern engines support infinite layers, but a game usually only needs 2-4ish, depending heavily on the blending techniques used.

[quote=“Davidi2, post:14, topic:520285”]I don’t mean they would all be actional objects, just objects in general that would be on the second layer(bushes, flowers, etc), but yea some of them would be actionable. But ignoring actions for now, can you explain what you meant a bit further, specifically ‘editor tricks’ to make the two layers appear like three.

Also slightly unrelated, but for a grid-by-grid walking system instead of free roam, do you know if it matters if I have a static screen size and have the regions match it (the map never moves), or have the map centered on the player (would mean larger regions), or something else? Or which players would prefer?[/quote]

I just mean that most situations can be done using two layers, instead of needing more. Some people may think there are different levels of background geometry (ie grass, stone, dirt, etc.) and thus each level can be represented by a different layer, where you just control some blend factor between them (more evident in terrains than in tilemaps, but similar idea). Although this works perfectly well and is quite convenient to develop, it’s not common for a single tile to be blending between all four or even three of the types in question. Usually you only see blending between stone and dirt, dirt and grass, etc. Rarely do you need to support blending (or a mixture) of all three simultaneously. Thus, even though multiple layers is convenient, most of the time you are only going to see a single background type tile and a single foreground type tile together.

You mention lighting tiles. That would be an excellent example of when a third layer would be quite convenient to support. You have several options in this case. You could bake multiple layers together, thus only requiring 2 or even 1 single layer, otherwise you can add more layers and increase the amount of blending. Essentially, it’s a CPU versus memory situation, since baking is a one-time cost with a memory loss and a draw time gain. Adding more layers saves memory but requires more draw time. To each their own.

I’m not exactly sure what you mean by the movement system. Regardless of the region size, you’re still going to need to stitch the regions together so when the camera moves past the edge of a region, it’s viewing parts of multiple regions at one time. The camera being centered on the player is a good option, though. It’s really up to you from a design perspective. If you prefer the way pokemon does it, then center the camera on the player, making sure to add constraints to stop the camera when you’re on the edge of the loaded area (unless it’s truly seamless, in which case you have to be careful when you’re on the edge of the entire game world). Otherwise if you really like the area-by-area feel, you could make it so the camera is centered on the region, like you mentioned, and just load a new region everytime the player goes off screen, moving the player to the other side and continuing with the new area. I can’t give you advice one way or the other, because it’s a completely opinionated decision.

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:15, topic:520285”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=638783.msg4306100#msg4306100 date=1369846742]
Just a bit of feedback on the per-tile information, I very rarely see games need 3 layers. They may provide the illusion of having three layers, since there are tiles you can walk on (layer below), tiles you cannot walk on (same layer), and tiles that are above you when you walk on them (layer above). Nevertheless, even for tiles that are semi-transparent being drawn on a background tile, that’s still only 2 visual layers. I pretty much never see transparent tiles on transparent tiles on an opaque tile (3 layers). Reconsider just implementing 2 layers and implementing some nice editor tricks for making it seem like 3. Unless, of course, I’m misunderstanding your intended goals.[/quote]GBA game use 4 layers. I’m sure the DS does the same or something similar.[/quote]Is the topmost layer for lighting effects or something? I noticed in my tilesheets there were some lighting (semi-transparent) tiles

But ignoring actions for now, can you explain what you meant a bit further, specifically ‘editor tricks’ to make the two layers appear like three.

Also slightly unrelated, but for a grid-by-grid walking system instead of free roam, do you know if it matters if I have a static screen size and have the regions match it (the map never moves), or have the map centered on the player (would mean larger regions), or something else? item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

I had a feeling the first bit was unnecessary right when I was submitting it, oh well.

I wasn’t aware you wanted object support. You could support “objects” just by making certain tiles “actionable,” wherein you can perform an action on them by some key or walk over or something. That way you’re only introducing a single bit per tile instead of needing another ID. If you really need object support, then it will be similar to three layers to store the object ID, but you could also store a list of objects separate from the tile data, then store a locator for each ID which represents which tile the object exists on (a bit opposite to I was saying above). This is a good solution because there will be few objects, so you’ll end up saving a lot more space this way versus storing a “null object” for most of the tiles, since most will probably not have an object.

All depends on what you’re planning on doing with it.

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:11, topic:520285”]To slightly counter the thoughts going on here (for giggles), the format you have will have a tremendous amount of redundant data (especially if you make the change I’ll suggest in a bit), which means any sort of compression algorithm that uses RLE (essentially most of them) will massively compress (hehe oxymoron) your file. If you do the changes I suggest, try creating one of the map files and then compressing it with LZMA or BZIP2 and see how significantly the size drops. Hell, even ZIP will have a noticeable size-down.

Now, my main suggestion is the lack of a need to story tilex/y. From what I’ve seen, region files usually contain information for every single tile in a region. Thus, you really only need to specify width and height, and even that is unnecessary if all regions are the exact same size. Thus, just store the per-tile information in an CONSECUTIVELY INTERLACED way (which will speedup cache coherency when reading in the file format in chunks) one tile after another, for every tile in the region. This may result in a bigger file, but it doesn’t have to deal with maintaining a list of placed tiles. You’ll benefit more from helping a RLE-compression algorithm and designing the format for cache-coherency than trying to make it really small by yourself. There are some circumstances for various different format standards and you really don’t have an outstanding need for anything in particular.[/quote]I’m not sure what you mean by ‘storing tilex/y’, do you mean from the tilesheet, or for the map tile itself? I actually don’t store that information, thanks for reminding me It would just be width/height, yea.

[quote=“Taharok, post:11, topic:520285”]Also, as far as the x/y from the tilesheet, you can just use a packed index instead of separate x/y values (ie, treat the tilesheet like an array of images rather than a tilesheet).[/quote]I don’t know why I didn’t think of that… my tileset handling already puts it into a 1D array instead of 2D. I had every single tile packed, it was like 0-10200 or something, but I forgot I could just use the id per-tileset, which would only go up to ~400 or so.

From what I’m understanding, to use 2 layers instead of 3, it would be something like
Layer 0 (below), Layer 1 (above), objects (below)

Then I would have to have a list of all of the objects and their relative sprite ids as well, and I don’t see how storing that object ID would be easier than storing the tileid as a different layer. Unless I’m misunderstanding what you mean.

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

To slightly counter the thoughts going on here (for giggles), the format you have will have a tremendous amount of redundant data (especially if you make the change I’ll suggest in a bit), which means any sort of compression algorithm that uses RLE (essentially most of them) will massively compress (hehe oxymoron) your file. If you do the changes I suggest, try creating one of the map files and then compressing it with LZMA or BZIP2 and see how significantly the size drops. Hell, even ZIP will have a noticeable size-down.

Now, my main suggestion is the lack of a need to story tilex/y. From what I’ve seen, region files usually contain information for every single tile in a region. Thus, you really only need to specify width and height, and even that is unnecessary if all regions are the exact same size. Thus, just store the per-tile information in an CONSECUTIVELY INTERLACED way (which will speedup cache coherency when reading in the file format in chunks) one tile after another, for every tile in the region. This may result in a bigger file, but it doesn’t have to deal with maintaining a list of placed tiles. You’ll benefit more from helping a RLE-compression algorithm and designing the format for cache-coherency than trying to make it really small by yourself. There are some circumstances for various different format standards and you really don’t have an outstanding need for anything in particular.

Just a bit of feedback on the per-tile information, I very rarely see games need 3 layers. They may provide the illusion of having three layers, since there are tiles you can walk on (layer below), tiles you cannot walk on (same layer), and tiles that are above you when you walk on them (layer above). Nevertheless, even for tiles that are semi-transparent being drawn on a background tile, that’s still only 2 visual layers. I pretty much never see transparent tiles on transparent tiles on an opaque tile (3 layers). Reconsider just implementing 2 layers and implementing some nice editor tricks for making it seem like 3. Unless, of course, I’m misunderstanding your intended goals.

Really, each tile just needs to store a tile id for the upper layer and the lower layer, then the collision type (walk over, don’t collide, walk under). Also, as far as the x/y from the tilesheet, you can just use a packed index instead of separate x/y values (ie, treat the tilesheet like an array of images rather than a tilesheet).

Just my 2c.

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:9, topic:520285”]The main problem is you’re assuming you’ll only ever needs X tilesheets, and X tiles, but you never know what the future may have in stall. Think minecraft and their mistakes.[/quote]I did overestimate quite a bit because I thought of that. The main reason I’m using X and Y coordinates instead of having a huge tile atlas with every tile is exactly for that reason, it doesn’t matter how many sheets I have, it’s completely expandable until I get to 255 tilesets (# of tiles completely expands) or if I need to reference more than 15 tilesets in a single map, which I think is outrageous. I estimated I’d never need more than 5, so I figured 15 was over-the-top.

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:9, topic:520285”]As Lin said, there’s no need to program like it’s 1983, you could even store data “normally” and just use a standard compression technique (obviously there are more cycles involved here, but it’s a lot more convenient)[/quote]Technically I could even compress this method

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

The main problem is you’re assuming you’ll only ever needs X tilesheets, and X tiles, but you never know what the future may have in stall. Think minecraft and their mistakes.

As Lin said, there’s no need to program like it’s 1983, you could even store data “normally” and just use a standard compression technique (obviously there are more cycles involved here, but it’s a lot more convenient)

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:7, topic:520285”]In modern games, there is absolutely no point in using bitmaps for maps unless you have to constantly send the data to peers like RuneScape. Besides, it’s not at all noticeable but you’re hurting performance this way by taking more cycles than just reading a couple bytes for tile properties.[/quote]The maps wouldn’t be sent that way at all, or used at all in bitmap format once it gets read initially. As for reading it, you’re right it would be very slightly less efficient this way, but I’m talking more about file format to make it as small as possible.

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

In modern games, there is absolutely no point in using bitmaps for maps unless you have to constantly send the data to peers like RuneScape. Besides, it’s not at all noticeable but you’re hurting performance this way by taking more cycles than just reading a couple bytes for tile properties.

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“tigerclan, post:4, topic:520285”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=638783.msg4305855#msg4305855 date=1369783559]

What is this for? A PC game? If that’s the case, I definitely wouldn’t worry about filesize.
[/quote]PC game, but it’s still good practice to be as efficient as possible, right?

And I figured it might tie well into a tutorial I was going to release about bit manipulation and how you can use it for file saving, wanted to make sure I got my information at least somewhat correct (been a while since I’ve done any of this stuff)

Not when its 26kb. That’s plenty small. Don’t trade quality for redundant performance. If it doesn’t run slow, then you shouldn’t worry about performance.[/quote]What do you mean ‘quality’?

Read full topic

item.title: 2D tile map file format
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

It’s still good practice… performance, performance, performance.
